section.text: A phrase is a series of notes that sound complete even when played apart from the main song.
We will use the above musical example to demonstrate phrases.
Listen to the first two bars, notice how they sound incomplete.
Now listen to the first four bars, it now sounds more complete.
These bars could be considered a phrase.
Listen to the fifth through eighth bars.
Due to their completeness, they also form a phrase.
A cadence is a two-chord progression that occurs at the end of a phrase.
If a phrase ends with any chord going to V, an imperfect cadence (ImC) occurs.
Listen again to the first four bars and notice the sound of the imperfect cadence.
Most people will hear an imperfect cadence as sounding incomplete. Because of this, composers usually will follow imperfect cadences with a phrase ending in a perfect cadence (PeC).
A perfect cadence occurs whenever a phrase ends with V going to I (or i if minor) in root position.
Listen to the above example, noting the sound of both cadences.
In addition to perfect and imperfect cadences, two other kinds exist.
If a phrase ends with IV (or iv) going to I (or i), a plagal cadence (PlC) occurs.
Listen to the above example, note the sound of the plagal cadence.
If a phrase ends with V going to vi (or VI in minor), an interupted cadence (InC) occurs.
Interupted cadences are often used in place of a perfect cadence.
Recall the musical example used at the beginning of this lesson. Notice that we have replaced the perfect cadence at the end of the second phrase with an interupted cadence.
Listen to the modified example. Notice how the cadence feels "interupted" (since you are expecting to hear a I).
